June 16, 1991: Fiction
LOVES MUSIC, LOVES TO DANCE, by Mary Higgins Clark. (Simon & Schuster,
$21.95.) Two Manhattan women, doing research into personal ads, get caught in
the snare of a serial killer.
HEIR TO THE EMPIRE, by Timothy Zahn. (Spectra/Bantam, $15.) The survival of
the "Star Wars" galaxy is menaced by new forces.
OH, THE PLACES YOU'LL GO! by Dr. Seuss. (Random House, $12.95.) The
problems of finding your way through life; in verse and pictures.
AS THE CROW FLIES, by Jeffrey Archer. (HarperCollins, $22.95.) Inspired by his
grandfather, a London vendor, a man strives to create the biggest store in the
world.
THE FIRM, by John Grisham. (Doubleday, $19.95.) A young lawyer learns that his
firm is engaged in secret, possibly illegal activities.
"H" IS FOR HOMICIDE, by Sue Grafton. (Holt, $17.95.) The private eye Kinsey
Millhone on the trail of two perpetrators of an insurance scam.
HEARTBEAT, by Danielle Steel. (Delacorte, $21.95.) A chance meeting of a man
and a woman enables them to solve romantic problems.
VORTEX, by Larry Bond. (Warner, $21.95.) A war in southern Africa sometime in
the future involves Cuba and the United States.
THE CROWN OF COLUMBUS, by Michael Dorris and Louise Erdrich.
(HarperCollins, $21.95.) A couple who have long disagreed about everything find
understanding on a Caribbean research trip.
THE SEERESS OF KELL, by David Eddings. (Del Rey/Ballantine, $20.) The fifth
volume in the "Malloreon" fantasy saga.
IMMORTALITY, by Milan Kundera. (Grove Weidenfeld, $21.95.) Through the lives
of characters in 19th-century Weimar and present-day Paris, the author reflects on
contemporary life.
POSSESSION, by A. S. Byatt. (Random House, $22.95.) A pair of British
academics pursue the relationship between two Victorian poets.
HOW TO MAKE AN AMERICAN QUILT, by Whitney Otto. (Villard, $18.) The
reminiscences of eight women, members of a quilting circle.
BRIGHT CAPTIVITY, by Eugenia Price. (Doubleday, $20.) Romance comes to a
plantation owner's daughter during the War of 1812.
THE CAT WHO KNEW A CARDINAL, by Lilian Jackson Braun. (Putnam, $16.95.)
Non-Fiction
THE COMMANDERS, by Bob Woodward. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) How the
President and his high military commanders made their decisions during the first
two years of the Bush Administration.
IRON JOHN, by Robert Bly. (Addison-Wesley, $18.95.) The passage of the male
from boyhood into manhood, as practiced in various cultures.
NANCY REAGAN, by Kitty Kelley. (Simon & Schuster, $24.95.) An unauthorized
biography.
COUNSEL TO THE PRESIDENT, by Clark Clifford with Richard Holbrooke.
(Random House, $25.) The memoirs of the lawyer who served as adviser to
several generations of Democrats.
WOODY ALLEN, by Eric Lax. (Knopf, $24.) The life of the film director, writer and
actor.
REAL PONIES DON'T GO OINK! by Patrick F. McManus. (Holt, $16.95.) A
humorist's essays about life's foibles at home and in the great outdoors.
IF YOU REALLY LOVED ME, by Ann Rule. (Simon & Schuster, $22.95.) The
murder of a young Orange County, Calif., woman.
YOU'LL NEVER EAT LUNCH IN THIS TOWN AGAIN, by Julia Phillips. (Random
House, $22.) A producer's experiences in Hollywood.
FIRE IN THE BELLY, by Sam Keen. (Bantam, $19.95.) A philosopher explores the
changing role of the male in today's society.
BULLY FOR BRONTOSAURUS, by Stephen Jay Gould. (Norton, $22.95.) Thirty-
five essays on natural history.
THERE ARE NO CHILDREN HERE, by Alex Kotlowitz. (Talese/Doubleday,
$21.95.) Two brothers growing up on Chicago's mean streets.
SILENT COUP, by Len Colodny and Robert Gettlin. (St. Martin's, $24.95.) The
events that led to the resignation of President Richard Nixon.
ILLIBERAL EDUCATION, by Dinesh D'Souza. (Free Press, $19.95.) A critical
account of the way matters of race and sex are treated on campus.
SLEEPWALKING THROUGH HISTORY, by Haynes Johnson. (Norton, $24.95.) A
social history of America during the Reagan era.
IN OUR DEFENSE, by Ellen Alderman and Caroline Kennedy. (Morrow, $22.95.)
How the Bill of Rights affects Americans' lives today.
